Finding the Real Subject After the Verb or Opener (Here/There + Questions)
ENGLISH (Main Explanation)
In inverted sentences, the verb comes before the subject. This makes the sentence look confusing, but the real subject is still the noun that controls the verb.
Confusing look â€” Inversion often uses here/there openers or questions.
Here / There opener â€” There are many students outside. (students = plural)
Here / There opener â€” Here comes the teacher. (teacher = singular)
Question â€” Where are the modules? (modules = plural)
Question â€” Is the answer correct? (answer = singular)
Key idea â€” Find the noun that tells you whether the verb should be singular or plural.
Example â€” There is a girl waiting. (girl = singular)
Example â€” There are two boys outside. (boys = plural)
Example â€” Where are the papers? (papers = plural)
Example â€” Where is your folder? (folder = singular)
Very simple â€” Ignore here/there or the question word. Look for the noun. That noun decides the verb.
